title: Dow skids 600 points as Powell vows to fight inflation 'until the job is done'; Investors also mull improving data on inflation, consumer sentiment
text:
How are stocks trading?

* S&P 500 SPX was down 90 points, or 2.2%, to 4,108.

* Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 606 points, or 1.8%, to 32,683.

* Nasdaq Composite COMP fell 335 points, or 2.7%, to 12,303.

Thursday marked the best session in two weeks for all three major indexes, with the S&P 500 SPX rising 1.4% to 4,199.12, the Dow industrials DJIA climbing 322.55 points, or 1%, to close at 33,291.78 and the Nasdaq Composite COMP advancing 1.7% to 12,639.27.

What's driving the market?

In remarks that appeared even more hawkish than many investors anticipated, Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell tried to dispel any hopes for a less-aggressive monetary policy stance by insisting that the central bank will persist in its inflation fight, even if that means causing some near-term economic pain for American families.

"Reducing inflation is likely to require a sustained period of below-trend growth," Powell said.

"Moreover, there will very likely be some softening of labor market conditions. While higher interest rates, slower growth, and softer labor market conditions will bring down inflation, they will also bring some pain to households and businesses."

Jake Jolly, senior investment strategist at BNY Mellon Investment Management, said Powell's remarks solidified his stay-tough stance.

"The market was pretty clearly set up for a hawkish 'sticking to the script' type of speech and the initial impression is that was what Chair Powell delivered â€” and he did in in less than 10 minutes," Jolly said.

"The key takeaway is he closed the door on this idea that there is going to be a short-term pivot on Fed policy."

Read: How stocks perform as central bankers gather each year at Jackson Hole

As Wall Street's selloff accelerated, Wall Street's "fear gauge," the CBOE Volatility Index VIX was up 1.3%, after climbing as high as 9.4% to 23.82. It briefly topped 24 earlier in the week. Treasury yields also rose in response to Powell, with the spread between the two-year and 10-year Treasury yields moving further into inverted territory.

Ahead of Powell's remarks, a batch of fresh data was released, including the headline PCE inflation index, which dropped 0.1% for July and to 6.3% from 6.8% annually.

The core PCE price index, closely watched by Fed policy makers, rose 0.1% on a one-month basis but decelerated by a slightly bigger-than-expected amount to a 4.5% year-over-year rate, from 4.8%,

Read: Inflation falls in July for the first time in 20 months, key gauge shows

Personal incomes climbed 0.2% in July, while consumer spending rose 0.1%, below forecast. The U.S. trade in goods deficit sank 9.7% in July, while inventories rose.

As Powell spoke, investors also received an update from the University of Michigan's survey of consumer sentiment, which showed that consumers' outlook on the economy improved in August, while medium- and long-term inflation expectations continued to moderate.

What companies are in focus?

* Electronics Arts Inc. EA shares rose 4.6% even after reports denied earlier rumors about a potential deal with Amazon.com Inc. AMZN.

* Shares of Dell Technologies Inc. DELL fell 11.8% after executives said the end of the pandemic-driven PC sales boom appeared in the second quarter. Revenue fell short of analysts expectations.

* Gap Inc. GPS stock fell 1.5%, erasing earlier gains that had followedan earnings report that slightly beat Wall Street expectations.

* Meta Platforms Inc. META and Amazon were both more than 3% as mega cap 'FAANG' names declined on Powell's hawkish remarks. Apple Inc. AAPL was down 2%. Netflix Inc. NFLX was down 3.4%.

How are other assets trading ?

* Crude prices turned lower. West Texas Intermediate crude CL.1 CLV22 fell 0.3% to $92.27 a barrel.

* The yield on the 10-year Treasury note BX:TMUBMUSD10Y was flat at 3.03%, while the 2-year note yield BX:TMUBMUSD02Y rose 3 basis points to 3.42%.

* Gold prices GC00 fell 1.3%, while the ICE Dollar Index DXY was flat at 108.47.

* Bitcoin BTCUSD slipped 4.5% to $20,502.
